title: 109_hr476
content: The "Family and Medical Leave Enhancement Act of 2005" amends the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 to change the eligibility criteria for employees from "less than 50" to "fewer than 25". Additionally, it provides additional entitlement to leave for parental involvement. The Family and Medical Leave Enhancement Act of 2005 expands parental involvement leave entitlement under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. Eligible employees can take up to 24 hours of leave in a 12-month period to participate in school or community activities related to their child or grandchild's program. The term 'school' refers to elementary or secondary schools, Head Start programs, and licensed child care facilities. 'Community organization' is defined as a nonprofit organization representing a community and providing activities. The Family and Medical Leave Act is amended to allow intermittent or reduced leave schedules for individuals in certain organizations. Paid leave can be substituted under specific circumstances, and employees must provide at least seven days' notice for leave requests. The Family and Medical Leave Act now allows intermittent or reduced leave schedules for certain individuals. Employees must give at least seven days' notice before taking leave. Employers can require certification for parental involvement leave requests. SEC. 4. ENTITLEMENT TO LEAVE FOR CIVIL SERVANTS FOR PARENTAL INVOLVEMENT. Section 6382(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to provide employees with additional leave to participate in school or community activities related to their child's education. Employees are entitled to four hours of leave every 30 days and 24 hours of leave every 12 months for this purpose. The Head Start Act and State-licensed child care facilities are included in the definition of community organizations. Employees can take intermittent or reduced leave under subsection (a)(3)(A) of the amended title 5, United States Code. Paid leave can be substituted for leave taken under subsection (a)(3)(A). Employees can request leave under subsection (a)(3)(A) of the amended title 5, United States Code, with a requirement to provide the employing agency with at least seven days' notice. Employing agencies may also require certification for such leave as prescribed by the Office of Personnel Management. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF ENTITLEMENT TO LEAVE. Amendments are made to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and title 5 of the United States Code to include provisions for routine family medical care needs, such as transportation for medical appointments and visits to nursing homes for elderly relatives. The schedule under the Act is also modified. Amendments are made to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and title 5 of the United States Code to include provisions for routine family medical care needs. Amendments to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and Title 5 of the United States Code now include provisions for routine family medical care needs, such as expanding eligibility to include subparagraphs (E) and (F) in certain sections. Amendments to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and Title 5 now allow employers and employing agencies to require certification for routine family medical care needs under specific sections. The definition of "grandchild" is amended for both non-civil-service and civil-service employees under the Family and Medical Leave Act and Title 5, United States Code.
